title: 2000–01 Taça de Portugal
text:
The 2000–01 <a href="Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">Taça de Portugal</a> was the 61st edition of the Portuguese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> knockout tournament, organized by the <a href="Portuguese%20Football%20Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a> (FPF). The 2000–01 Taça de Portugal began in September 2000. The final was played on 10 June 2001 at the <a href="Est%C3%A1dio%20Nacional">Estádio Nacional</a>.
<a href="F.C.%20Porto">Porto</a> were the previous holders, having defeated <a href="Sporting%20Clube%20de%20Portugal">Sporting CP</a> 2–0 in the previous season's final in cup final which went to a replay. <a href="F.C.%20Porto">Porto</a> defeated <a href="C.S.%20Mar%C3%ADtimo">Marítimo</a>, 2–0 in the final to win their eleventh Taça de Portugal. As a result of Porto winning the domestic cup competition, they faced <a href="Boavista%20F.C.">Boavista</a> in the <a href="2001%20Superta%C3%A7a%20C%C3%A2ndido%20de%20Oliveira">2001 Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira</a>.
Fifth Round.
Ties were played between the 20 January, and the 31 January. Replays were played between the 3–9 January. <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">Benfica</a>'s away cup tie to <a href="Louletano%20D.C.">Louletano</a> on 21 December was abandoned due to poor weather conditions, and was rescheduled for 3 January.
Sixth Round.
Ties were played on the 16–17 January. Replays were played between the 23 January, and the 7 February. <a href="F.C.%20Pa%C3%A7os%20de%20Ferreira">Paços de Ferreira</a> took a <a href="Bye%20%28sports%29">bye</a> to the next round.
Quarter-finals.
All quarter-final ties were played on the 11–12 February.
Semi-finals.
Ties were played on the 21–22 March.
